case_name: Manohar Lal v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 173/1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 173/1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 23, 1956 of Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1058/1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 23, 1956, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1058/1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 11, 1960 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-This appeal

facts.text: Appellant Manohar Lal has a shop at Ferozepore Cantt. under name Imperial Book Depot.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-Manohar Lal--has a shop at Ferozepore Cantt. in which business is carried on under the name and style of I Imperial Book Depot.

facts.text: Appellant chose Friday as the close day for his shop.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had chosen Friday as the close day , i.e., the day of the week on which his shop would remain closed.

facts.text: Inspector of Shops and Commercial Establishments, Ferozepore Circle, visited appellant's shop on Friday, January 29, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Inspector of Shops and Commercial Establishments, Ferozepore Circle, visited the appellants shop on Friday, the 29th of January, 1954,

facts.text: On January 29, 1954, appellant's shop was found open and appellant's son was selling articles.

anchor.surface_text: and found the shop open and the appellants son selling articles. Obviously, if s. 7 1  were valid,

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted in Court of Additional District Magistrate, Ferozepore under s.16 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was guilty of a companytravention of its terms and he was accordingly prosecuted in the Court of the Additional District Magistrate, Ferozepore,

facts.text: Appellant admitted the facts of the shop being open.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted the facts but he pleaded that the Act would number apply to his shop

facts.text: Appellant claimed no strangers engaged as employees, work done by himself and family members.

anchor.surface_text: but that the entire work in the shop was being done by himself and by the members of his family, and that to hold that s. 7 1

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate rejected constitutionality plea and sentenced appellant to fine of Rs. 100.

anchor.surface_text: The additional District Magistrate rejected the plea raised by the appellant regarding the companystitutionality of s. 7 1

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to simple imprisonment in default of fine payment.

anchor.surface_text: sentenced him to a fine of Rs. 100 and simple imprisonment in default of payment of the fine  since the appellant

facts.text: Appellant had been convicted once before.

anchor.surface_text: since the appellant had been companyvicted once before . The appellant applied to the High Court of Punjab

facts.text: Appellant applied for revision to Punjab High Court, revision dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the High Court of Punjab to revise this order, but the Revision was dismissed.

facts.text: Punjab High Court granted certificate of fitness under Arts. 132 and 134.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges, however, granted a cer- tificate of fitness which has enabled the appellant to file the appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant challenged s.7(1) as violative of Arts. 14, 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: and that to hold that s. 7 1  of the Act would be unconstitutional as violative of the fundamental rights guaranteed by Arts. 14, 19 1  f  and  g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant argued violation of Art.19(1)(g), restriction not reasonable under Art.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: He urged that the provision violated the appellants right to carry on his trade or business guaranteed by Art. 19 1  g  and that the restriction imposed was number reasonable within Art. 19 6

facts.text: Supreme Court repelled challenge to constitutionality of s.7(1).

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the submissions of the learned Counsel should be repelled.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940  hereinafter called the Act , enacts 7.  1  Save as otherwise provided by this Act, every shop or commercial establishment shall remain closed on a close day.

issues.text: Is s. 7(1) of the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940 constitutional?

anchor.surface_text: of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Punjab raises for companysideration the companystitutionality of s. 7 1  of the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940. The appellant-Manohar Lal--has a shop at Ferozepore Cantt. in which business is carried on under the name and style of I Imperial Book Depot.

issues.text: Does the Punjab Trade Employees Act, 1940 apply to shops or establishments where no strangers are engaged as employees and all work is done by family members?

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted the facts but he pleaded that the Act would number apply to his shop or establishment for the reason that he had engaged numberstrangers as employees but that the entire work in the shop was being done by himself and by the members of his family, and that to hold that s. 7 1

holdings.text: The submissions of the learned Counsel should be repelled.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the submissions of the learned Counsel should be repelled. The long title of the Act extracted earlier and on which learned Counsel placed considerable reliance as a guide for the determination of the scope of the Act and the policy underlying the legislation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects challenges to constitutionality and applicability; long title does not control provisions; promotes health and welfare; reasonable under Art.19(6); prevents evasion.

holdings.text: The long title of the Act indicates the main purposes of the enactment but cannot, obviously, control the express operative provisions of the Act, such as for example the terms of s. 7(1).

anchor.surface_text: The long title of the Act extracted earlier and on which learned Counsel placed considerable reliance as a guide for the determination of the scope of the Act and the policy underlying the legislation, no doubt, indicates the main purposes of the enactment but cannot, obviously, control the express operative provisions of the Act, such as for example the terms of s. 7(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Title guides scope and policy but subordinate to express terms like s.7(1); does not limit application to employee shops.

holdings.text: Nor is the learned counsel right in his argument that the terms of s. 7(1) are irrelevant to secure the purposes or to subserve the underlying policy of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is the learned counsel right in his argument that the terms of s. 7(1) are irrelevant to secure the purposes or to subserve the underlying policy of the Act. The ratio of the legislation is social interest in the health of the worker who forms an essential part of the community and in whose welfare, therefore, the community is vitally interested.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(1) advances Act's health protection goal for workers, applicable even without strangers employed.

holdings.text: A restriction imposed with a view to secure this purpose would, in our opinion, be clearly saved by Art. 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: The legislation is in effect the exercise of social control over the manner in which business should be carried on-regulated in the interests of the health and welfare not merely of those employed in it but of all those engaged in it. A restriction imposed with a view to secure this purpose would, in our opinion, be clearly saved by Art. 19(6).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulates business for health/welfare of employees and owners; reasonable restriction in interest of general public.

holdings.text: The constitutionality of the impugned provision might be sustained on another ground also, viz., with a view to avoid evasion of provisions specifically designed for the protection of workmen employed.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this, the constitutionality of the impugned provision might be sustained on another ground also, viz., with a view to avoid evasion of provisions specifically designed for the protection of workmen employed. It may be pointed out that acts innocent in themselves may be prohibited and the restrictions in that regard would be reasonable, if the same were necessary to secure the efficient enforcement of valid provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative justification: prevents evasion by family-run shops hiring sporadically; margin for enforcement reasonable.

holdings.text: Acts innocent in themselves may be prohibited and the restrictions in that regard would be reasonable, if the same were necessary to secure the efficient enforcement of valid provisions.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that acts innocent in themselves may be prohibited and the restrictions in that regard would be reasonable, if the same were necessary to secure the efficient enforcement of valid provisions. The inclusion of a reasonable margin to ensure effective enforcement will not stamp a law otherwise valid as within legislative competence with the character of unconstitutionality as being unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle for upholding restrictions aiding enforcement of worker protections.

holdings.text: We have, therefore, no hesitation in repelling the attack on the constitutionality of s. 7(1) of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative reasons affirm no violation of Art.19(1)(g); upholds conviction.

precedents.citation: Manohar Lal v. The State 1951 S.C.R. 671, 675

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in Manohar Lal v. The State 1   when the appellant challenged the validity of this identical provision but on other grounds  The legislature may have felt it necessary, in order to reduce the possibilities of evasion to a minimum, to encroach upon the liberties of those who would number otherwise have been affected To require a shopkeeper, who employs one or two men,  1  1951 S.C.R. 671, 675. to close and permit his rival, who employs perhaps a dozen members of his family, to remain open, clearly places the former at a grave companymercial disadvantage. To permit such a distinction might well engender discontent and in the end react upon the relations between employer and employed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature can encroach upon liberties of those who would not otherwise be affected to reduce possibilities of evasion of provisions designed for protection of workmen.
precedents.cited_holding: The legislature may have felt it necessary, in order to reduce the possibilities of evasion to a minimum, to encroach upon the liberties of those who would number otherwise have been affected.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this, the constitutionality of the impugned provision might be sustained on another ground also, viz., with a view to avoid evasion of provisions specifically designed for the protection of workmen employed. It may be pointed out that acts innocent in themselves may be prohibited and the restrictions in that regard would be reasonable, if the same were necessary to secure the efficient enforcement of valid provisions.
